messageBody:
I looked at it, and found it to be rather error prone, in that you
have to get every setup method as a before, and every teardown as an
after, change the constructor, etc. I didn't find a tool to do it.

The only problems I have with the hack code I presented are:

1) it is extremely brittle. I expect it to break with JUnit 4.6.
2) Intellij doesn't report the test name correctly. It reports:

Test 'com.intellij.rt.junit4.Junit4ClassSuite$1.0 test case(s)' ignored.

I assume it looks at the annotation and does its own naming.

The main reason I'm asking on the group is in case I'm missing
something about the approach, and perhaps the JUnit developers had
something else in mind. Clearly they do for JUnit 4 tests, but I
haven't found anything for intermixing JUnit 3 tests.

I do appreciate the insight about the Assume class, it is very helpful
to know!
